author: Stephanie Chalkley-Rhoden
title: AFLW: Balancing the hope and expectations of women's football in its first season - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Map: VIC 
When the Australian Football League decides it wants something, it usually gets it. 
And the executive's decision to back women's football will have a profound affect on women's sport in general, boosting its profile, bargaining power and competition for athletes. 
It's genuinely ground-breaking and too long in the making. Young girls who dream of playing football for Carlton or Collingwood now know it can become reality. Hope is a wonderful thing. 
But it's important that people reign in their expectations in the first few years of the competition. 
Last year's exhibition match between Melbourne and the Western Bulldogs surprised fans with its pace, ferocity and exciting play. But this was essentially an all-star game. 
It created hype around the competition that it craved and needed. It made Moana Hope and Daisy Pearce into household names. But it also created a high benchmark. 
For decades, the men's game has had clear development pathways to help boys progress to senior football — the level of coaching and support at Under 18 level is immense. 
Women have not had those luxuries. Some local clubs don't even have female-friendly change rooms. 
There are code hoppers — women who played basketball, soccer, even an Olympic javelin thrower — who are athletes but not necessarily football players. 
The pool of talent is not as deep once it is spread across eight teams. That was one reason why the AFL limited the number of teams in this first phase. 
The competition needs time to develop, to find its feet and to grow the talent from the ground up. 
Hopefully, what we see in five or ten years will be lightyears ahead of what we see on Friday night. That's no slight on the women who have the chance to make history this weekend. 
It's the hope that the next generation — the girls who are 10,12 and 13-years-old — will have grown up in those elite pathways that were until now only available for boys, and their skills will be so much better. A throw back to the 'good old days' of tribal football Photo: Improving opportunities at grassroots level will help the elite competition get stronger. (Supplied: Leah Kaslar) 
So why should you bother watching if it still needs time? Because this will be footy in its purest sense. 
It will be played with joy, passion and without pressure of expectation or history. It will (hopefully) be free-flowing and not bogged down by tactics, zones and the defensive press. 
You may have noticed the players speak honestly, openly and without 'one week at at time' cliches. Perhaps that will change as it becomes more professional, but until then it should be embraced. 
We tend to dream about the good old days of suburban grounds, of leaning over the fence and standing behind the goals. Here's your chance to go along to Princes Park and Whitten Oval, head out to the huddle at quarter-time and kick the footy when the siren sounds. Photo: The first round draft picks for the inaugural AFL Women's League. (Supplied: AFL Media) 
And let's be honest: as a footy fan, who doesn't want an opportunity to watch footy? 
Women's football will be great but it won't be the best, not just yet. Be patient with what you see because there's still a long way to go. 
But stand in the outer, cheer on the trailblazers and support the next generation. Get excited. 
That's the only way women's footy will reach its full potential, and you might just enjoy yourself in the process.
